Situation1: They remain cheerful and patient while handling an upset customer during a peak holiday rush.
Expectation2: Attend meetings and court sessions punctually
Situation2: They are expected at routine meetings that occur frequently
Story: The line at the register snakes around the corner, and the holiday music does nothing to soothe the tension in the air. As a cashier, I’m supposed to be the calm in the storm, smiling and patient, even as the customer in front of me raises their voice about a coupon that won’t scan. I nod, apologize, and try to fix the issue, feeling the eyes of the waiting crowd burning into me. My phone buzzes in my pocket—a reminder that the advocacy meeting starts in ten minutes. I’m expected to be there, on time, every time, to support my clients and speak up for their needs. My heart pounds. If I leave now, I’ll let down my manager and the customers who expect friendly, efficient service. If I stay, I’ll be late to the meeting, disappointing the people who rely on my advocacy. I grip the register, torn between the demands of both worlds, wishing I could split myself in two.
